#Text=Ken Hutchins

#Text=Ken Hutchins ( born 20th century ) is an American inventor who defined and popularized the Super Slow form of resistance training exercise , and developed methodology , trainer certifications , and exercise equipment to specifically support the techniques .
#Text=Career and activities
#Text=Hutchins was introduced in 1966 , to strength training by a family friend who explained the importance of physical strength to musicianship and built Hutchins his first weight bench .
#Text=Later , in 1968 , this friend introduced Hutchins to Ellington Darden , and through Darden in 1971 , Hutchins learned of Arthur Jones and Nautilus , Inc. strength-training principles .
#Text=Hutchins 's serious contributions to the field of exercise , began in 1975 when he served Darden as a proofreader and writer .
#Text=In 1977 , Hutchins was employed at Nautilus as a surgery technician , writer , surgical photographer , and proofreader .
#Text=From 1979 to 1982 , he served as inside salesperson and traveling speaker , addressing scores of Nautilus clinics yearly .

#Text=In 1982 , Hutchins and his wife , Brenda , were sent by [ Arthur Jones ] to Gainesville , Florida , to supervise the exercise program for the Nautilus-sponsored osteoporosis study at the University of Florida Medical School .
#Text=During this year , Hutchins wrote the SuperSlow Protocol article .
#Text=He refined its application with over 8,000 one-on-one workouts between 1982 and 1986 .
#Text=In 1986 , Hutchins worked as an exercise equipment designer and prototypist , specializing in the application of coupled movement arms .
#Text=In 1987 , he compiled historical developments of Nautilus equipment and wrote video scripts for detailed Nautilus education .

#Text=After leaving Nautilus , Hutchins established his own exercise practice , continuing to develop the Super Slow techniques and eventually publishing several editions of a technical manual [ 1 ] for the application of Super Slow exercise .
#Text=In the early 1990s , a certification program was developed for exercise professionals to bring standardization to SuperSlow training .

#Text=Hutchins developed an interest group , calling it the Super Slow Exercise Guild ( Inc. ) , which met to refine techniques and published articles in its newsletter , The Exercise Standard , from 1994 to 2000 .
#Text=Numerous similar methods have been spun off by members of the guild and others as their ideas or business models developed .

#Text=The New York Times Magazine included Super Slow and Hutchins in its Year in Ideas : An Encyclopedia of innovations , conceptual leaps , harebrained schemes , cultural tremors & hindsight reconings that made a difference in 2001 . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 2009 , Hutchins and his wife joined Renaissance Exercise , continuing to produce evolutionary designs for exercise equipment .
#Text=Expanded exercise technique and protocol descriptions [ 3 ] were published in 2011 .
#Text=Contributions
#Text=Hutchins 's major accomplishments during the Nautilus Osteoporosis Project were :
#Text=Composing the Exercise vs. Recreation Philosophy .
#Text=Discovering the principle of the variable counterbalance applied to counterbalance human bodytorque .
#Text=Identifying friction as a major issue in exercise equipment and motor control .
#Text=Identifying four major considerations for the first comprehensive definition of exercise .
#Text=Evolving photographic standardization for comparing the results of exercise and diet programs .
#Text=Discovering that all human muscular functions are negative-cam effects .
#Text=Identifying the conflict between assumed and real objective as a major psychological challenge in exercise .

#Text=In the early 1990s , Hutchins and his wife developed and patented the Linear Spine(R ) Machines for his company , SuperSlow ( R ) Systems , Inc. This equipment was designed to provide crucial exercise for severely debilitated back and abdominal musculatures .
